improving_at_table_tennis.probleme: General pathway to improve table tennis performance
causes_communes: Lack of qualified coaching and structured practice
Too little tournament experience and limited variety of opponents
Inadequate mental focus and poor point-by-point competitiveness
Practicing at speeds that reduce consistency; reaching instead of moving

debutant: Prioritize coaching (personal lessons or clinics) to learn correct habits.
Drill forehand-to-forehand and backhand-to-backhand; aim deep and wide on the table.
Do basic footwork: all-forehand while partner blocks to different sections; move to the ball, do not reach.
Practice serves and receive regularly; shadow-practice in front of a mirror when alone.
intermediaire: Add more advanced, specific drills as shown by a coach; always practice with a clear focus.
Study stronger players and copy effective technique details.
Enter tournaments beyond local events to face diverse styles and conditions; analyze opponents mid- and post-match.
Begin regular off-table conditioning: jump rope, wind sprints, weights, respiratory fitness to sustain late-tournament performance.
avance: Intentionally attack under pressure in matches to build reliability despite short-term losses.
Systematically vary competition settings to build 'tournament toughness' and broaden tactical exposure.
Integrate strength and conditioning cycles to add power and late-round endurance.
Cultivate a mental routine to fight for every point and make intelligent shot selection; review matches objectively to adjust style.

exercices_complementaires.nom: FH–FH and BH–BH depth & width control
exercices_complementaires.description: Rally forehand-to-forehand and backhand-to-backhand; place balls deep and alternately wide to corners; prioritize consistency over speed.
Hitter uses forehand from both wings while partner blocks to varying sections; mover adjusts feet each shot; avoid reaching.
Shadow swing core strokes and footwork in front of a mirror; check posture, swing path, recovery.

exercices_complementaires.nom: Conditioning circuit for quickness and power
exercices_complementaires.description: Jump rope and short sprints to increase foot speed; weight training for overall strength and power carryover.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: jump rope; open space; generic weights

erreurs_a_eviter: Reaching for the ball instead of moving the feet
Practicing too fast and sacrificing consistency
Avoiding new tactics in matches due to fear of losing
Failing to analyze opponents and conditions

develop_the_fundamentals_strokes_footwor.probleme: Insufficient fundamentals in strokes and footwork
develop_the_fundamentals_strokes_footwor.diagnostic: Players lack consistent repeating strokes and do not move into position, reducing reliability under varied spins, speeds, and placements.
causes_communes: Impatience with repetitive training; skipping basics as 'boring'
Reaching instead of moving, creating small effective hitting zones
Altering stroke form constantly instead of repeating a simple motion

debutant: Build repeating forehand and backhand drives until consistent.
Adopt the '100 theory': reach 100 consecutive forehand drives and 100 consecutive backhand drives with proper form.
Layer in basic footwork so each ball is contacted from position, not by reaching.
intermediaire: Perform drills with increasing variation and randomized placement to bring fundamentals into game-like conditions.
Maintain repeating strokes while only adjusting racket angle and trajectory to the incoming ball.
avance: Increase drill speed while preserving form; identify maximum pace at which fundamentals hold, then expand it through more drilling.
Develop a large repertoire (drives, loops, blocks, pushes, flips, lobs, chops) with consistent mechanics across incoming variations.

exercices_complementaires.description: Alternate FH–FH and BH–BH rallies; add side-to-side steps so each contact is made from balanced position.
Partner sends balls unpredictably to FH/BH; striker returns with the same repeating stroke, adjusting only angle and path.

metriques_progression: Complete 100 consecutive forehand drives with proper stroke.
Complete 100 consecutive backhand drives with proper stroke.
erreurs_a_eviter: Standing and reaching instead of moving the feet
Changing stroke mechanics on each ball
Assuming tactics and conditioning can replace weak fundamentals

terminologie_extrait.definition: A three-ball footwork pattern: partner sends two balls to your backhand and one to your wide forehand; you play backhand, then step around for a forehand from backhand corner, then forehand from wide forehand; repeat.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Advanced footwork section describing side-to-side patterns.

terminologie_extrait.definition: A pattern where one player goes crosscourt and the other down-the-line on each ball, creating continuous diagonal movement; can be done with forehands only.
terminologie_extrait.contexte: Optional drills under beginner and intermediate footwork.

killer_practice_sessions.probleme: Designing an effective, level-appropriate practice session
killer_practice_sessions.diagnostic: Players often choose drills mismatched to level or partner style and skip key session components, limiting transfer to matches.
causes_communes: Same drills for all players regardless of level, style, or equipment
Irregular practice frequency leading to unfocused sessions
Not progressing drills toward game-like patterns

debutant: Warm-up: FH–FH and BH–BH crosscourt, 7.5 min each; BH and FH pushing 5 min each; optional: attempt 100 in a row.
Footwork: alternate FH/BH while placing to one spot; 5 min each. All-forehand footwork vs. BH block to both courts; 5 min each.
Attack: serve backspin; partner pushes to a specified spot; loop and play out point; 7.5 min each.
Serve & receive: practice multiple serves; at least 1 minute per serve for a total of ~7.5 min each.
Match play: finish with practice games to apply techniques.
Solo: schedule dedicated serve practice and basic physical training (jump rope, sprints, bodyweight).
intermediaire: Warm-up: FH–FH and BH–BH crosscourt 2.5 min each; FH↔BH down-the-line 2.5 min each; FH loop vs. block 5 min each; optional pushing, BH loop, counterloop.
Footwork: side-to-side covering ~2/3 table for 7.5 min each; random FH/BH with fixed return location 5 min each; optional Figure 8 FH-only (10 min total).
Attack: serve short backspin; partner pushes to a specified area; loop and play out (5 min each). Repeat with random push placement, loop from appropriate wing (5 min each).
Serve & receive: server practices serve-and-attack patterns; receiver has two set receive options; 7.5 min each.
Specialized: choose two focus drills (e.g., BH loop development, counterlooping) for 7.5 min each player.
avance: Warm-up: FH–FH or FH→BH lines 2.5 min; BH–BH or BH→FH lines 2.5 min; FH loop vs. moving block 5 min each; optional BH loop, counterloop, full-table pushing.

Footwork: fast side-to-side (2/3 to full table) 5 min each; 2-1 (Falkenberg) 5 min each; random full-table placement with fixed return spot 5 min each; optional serve–push–loop into footwork continuation.

Attack: serve short backspin; partner pushes randomly; loop (FH from FH side; FH or BH from BH side); 7.5 min each. Optionally mix in occasional fast/deep serves or receiver attacks; or serve short sidespin, receiver flips wide, then attack and play out.
Serve & receive: build complex two-option trees (e.g., short backspin/topspin/no-spin/sidespin serves; receiver short/long push or flip to varied locations).
Specialized: tailor drills to style matchups (loop vs. chop, lobbing, smashing vs. block, looping a chopper); 7.5 min per chosen drill per player.

exercices_complementaires.description: FH–FH and BH–BH drives crosscourt; BH and FH pushing series; incorporate looping as level allows.
exercices_complementaires.duree: Segments of 2.5–7.5 minutes as listed by level

exercices_complementaires.description: Partner alternates placements; striker moves laterally each ball and returns to ready position.
Backhand from BH corner, step-around FH from BH corner, then FH from wide FH; repeat while placing to partner's BH.
Start with short backspin serve; partner pushes long; loop first ball, then continue into a lateral footwork rally.
Server repeats one serve; receiver alternates between two predefined receives; server prepares for both and continues point.

metriques_progression: Beginner warm-up segments: 5–7.5 minutes per listed drill.
Intermediate warm-up/footwork/attack segments: 2.5–7.5 minutes per listed drill.
Advanced footwork and attack segments: 5–7.5 minutes per listed drill.
erreurs_a_eviter: Using identical drills regardless of level or style
Failing to move the feet on every ball and to reset to ready position
Keeping drills non-match-like and never adding realistic starts
Overlooking solo serve practice and physical training between sessions
